captions.text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and today I'm bringing
you a really highly requested side dish of
Creamed Corn!

Now, I didn't know that this dish was so popular
and that so many of you wanted to see it,

and I wanted to share with you my version
because it's really simple, really easy, completely

adaptable to whether you like what I put in
there or not, and it's just easy, and a staple

in the summertime. Especially with some Jersey
fresh corn because it is really delicious.

So the ingredients you'll need are few and
basics, you'll need some fresh corn, and I

do think fresh is the way to go in this recipe,
I'll show you sort of how I cut it in just

a minute. Then I have some onions and bacon.
I've got a little bit of flour, in here I
have a mixture of heavy cream and whole milk.

You;ll need some salt and pepper, and you;ll
also need just a little bit of butter at the

end, so it's very simple, I always make my
creamed corn in a cast iron skillet just like

I make my corn bread, for some reason I Just
think it tastes much better. Don't ask.

Before I get going on cutting the last piece
of the corn - kernels off the corn cob - I

want to get my onions and my bacon sauteing.
Now by all means, if you - and put them both

together at the same time, and I don't have
any fat because the bacon is going to render

a lot of its own fat, so get those two mixed
together and let that go.

Now, if you - I know that some people do their
creamed corn with no onions and no bacon,

and just cream, corn, milk and butter and
salt and pepper.

I think since corn can be so sweet, I really
love the smokiness from the bacon. If you

don't want to use bacon, just use onion, just
use onion. If you don't want to use either

one, don't use either one. Just saute your
corn in a little bit of butter.

So this is what I do when I cut the kernels
off the cob. I use a bundt pan. Okay, pretty
much everyone has one of these in their house.

Cut the bottom off and just stick it right
in there and it holds itself up, and then

you take a sharp knife and you cut it right
down, and you want to make sure that you cut

off - wow - you cut off as close as possible
to the cob because you don't want to waste

any. Now, normally, you shouldn't get a mess
everywhere, but you know what it's like when

you're showing it to people it makes a liar
out of you. Ha!

I'm just going to continue to cut the corn
off the cob, it's really simple and really

easy, and then what I do is I just take the
back of the knife, and you see that? That's

called the milk - that's flavor galore, so
I like to just scrape that down with the back

of the knife and put that right in the bowl
as well.

That's looking exactly how I want it. It's
been about four minutes, so now I'm going

to add in all of my corn kernels. I love this
trick.
I tell ya, it is awesome!
So awesome!

Give this all a good stir, you want to make
sure that the corn is well coated in that

bacon fat or those bacon juices I suppose
you could call them.

I'm going to take just a little bit of flour,
about a tablespoon, and I am going to just

sprinkle that over the corn and give it a
stir, cooking it for about a minute. What

that's going to do is as everything cooks
together for a while, it's going to thicken

up the juices, or the sauce I suppose, and
it makes everything sort of velvety and creamy,
it just helps keep the texture really nicely.

That's good enough, I"m going to add in my
mixture now.

Give that a good stir, and now I want you
to cook this on low for about twenty five

minutes or so or until the corn is tender,
you can take it further if you wanted to,

if you want your corn to like completely fall
apart and be super creamy. I think twenty

- twenty five minutes is probably going to
be enough for me, that's what I prefer, I

prefer for my corn to still have a slight
crunch to it. And I'm not going to season

this until we're done cooking it because I
want to judge how much salt is in there from

the bacon, so I'm going to let this go and
then I will show you what it looks like when
it's there.

My creamed corn has been cooking for about
thirty minutes on medium-low, I just turned

the heat up for a little bit because I'm going
to add a couple tablespoons of butter. Now,

a couple tablespoons of butter might seem
like a lot, but of course if you have ever

had creamed corn before, then you know it's
not exactly the lightest dish in the world,

but it is so rich that you really only need
to eat a little bit of it, like for this we

would easily get enough for six servings as
a side dish, just because it is so rich and

you don't need a whole lot, so I'm just going
to give this a good stir and wait for my butter

to melt completely. Now, I have adjusted the
seasoning according to my taste, I seasoned

it and I felt like it needed a little salt
and pepper, which I've added. And now I'm

just going to stir in the butter until it's
melted and we'll be done!

That's looking great, I'm just going to turn
this off because that is done!

This is so good, I've already tasted it for
seasoning but this is going to taste ten times

better with that butter in it. Just going
to wait for it to kind of get a little cold
because it's hot!
Mmm.
Mmm!

It's just Joe and I so I'm going back in for
seconds. That is spot on!

That's how I like my creamed corn, I love
for my corn to be fresh and still have a slight

bite to it, I don't like for it to be too,
too mushy. I love the bacon, I love the slight

saltiness and smokiness but you could completely
leave it out if you don't want to have bacon,

just have the onions. Or if you don't want
to have onions, just saute your corn in a
little bit of butter and you will be in business!

Let me know how you like your creamed corn,
I hope you have enjoyed this recipe, and the

recipe will be on LauraintheKitchen.com of
course. I'll see you next time!
Bye bye!

title: Homemade Creamed Corn Recipe - Laura Vitale - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 795
